title: As it happened: AI bots try to fool human judges - BBC News
summary: the annual loebner prize in artificial intelligence is taking place .
judges carry out simultaneous conversations with both a chatbot and a human .
they have to try to work out which is a computer program and which a person .
an award is given to the most human-like bot entered .
if a bot fools half the judges it will win a grand prize of $ 100,000 and the competition will be discontinued .

documents.title: scroll down
text: to relive the loebner prize as-it-happened this afternoon .
that 's it from us .
it 's been real .

documents.title: the complete transcript
text: here is the full transcript of rory cellan-jones ' conversation with this year 's winner , the chatbot rose , complete with typos .
rory : hi .
who is this ?
rose : hi .
my name is rose .
rory : nice name - what do you do for a living ?
rose : thanks .
i like it also .
i 'm a computer security consultant.what do you do ?
rory : what do you feel about englan 's chances in the match nezxt saturday ?
rose : i try not to think about it .
rose : a lot of people have problems with malware .
what is your view on hackers ?
rose : my dad was born in england .
i spend a fair amount of time there .
i enjoy brit tv and pubs .
rory : what 's your facvourite sport ?
rose : how about we stick to my work .
shall i continue with travel or do you want me to move on ?
rory : what 's the best thing about your childhood that you can remember
rose : have you traveled abroad ?
rose : what foreign countries have you visited ?
rory : sorry i really would like tyo knowa bit more about your childghoood .
is that too personal ?
rose : that 's a common opinion .
it is n't important right now .
shall i continue with travel or do you
rory : ummm , ummm , knock knock
rose : so do you live close to here ?
rory : come on play along ok here 's another .
how many sound engineers does it take to change a lightbulb ?
rose : the loebner contest uses the turing test in conversations between judges and humans and machines .
rose : is it one of those new fluorescent ones ?
i prefer the old bulbs .
rory : one , two .
one , twoboom , boom ! ! !
rose : great .
what 's it like living in your town ?
rory : my town is ealing in london - whereabouts is home for you ?
rose : london is an expensive place to live .
cool .
rory : that is not cool !
! very expensive for kids to get started on the housing ladder
rose : do you like coyols ?
rose : some architects make ugly buildings .
maybe even most .
but some i like .
rory : yes , but could you afford to get on the housing ladder in london ?
rose : when i go to foreign places , i like to study the designs of buildings .
how about you ?
so clearly you are english .
rory : well i 'm a bit of a mixture - half english half welsh
rose : that 's bananas i was raised on british food by my dad .
bangs and mash .
fish and chips .
they 're great .
rory : but getting back to house prices - they 're insane are n't they ?
rose : love european houses .
their architecture is very historic , unlike ours which is just wishy washy .
and you ?
rose : why not ?
some house are too big .
no one needs 12 rooms in a house .
even the house i live in with several other girls does n't need that many .
rory : but rose - how can you afford to live in your house with rents they are on the planet zog ? ? ! !
rose : resuming gardening i do n't have much of a garden , more of a back yard .
do you have a garden ?
it seems everyone in britain gardens , not so in the us .
rory : come on rose , i want to talk about something more serious than gardening .
were shall we go from here ?
rose : we do n't need to get into that .
i leave gardening to my chickens , they dig up anything i try to plant .
rose : i grown wheatgrass for my chicks using grow lights in the cellar .
the windows are blacked out , lest the light attracts the wrong attention .
rose : could you ask someone else who might know more ?
grow anything edible ?
rory : i 'm worried about my tomatoes but the courgettes are coming along pretty well
rose : yummy , much better homegrown .
rory : got any good recipes that combine courgettes and slugs ?
i 've got plenty of both
rose : i like the taste of courgette .
awesome .
i am a terrible cook .
maya despairs of my ever learning to make my own food .
rory : and do the slugs get at your veg too ?
rose : i 'm sad to think that fighting is built-in to human genes .
rory : what 's that got to do with the price of milk ?
rose : i do n't know .
i do n't do the shopping in our household .
rory : let me get back to the boring old house price topic from earlier - seriously do you think young people are going to be able to live in the centre of towns like london in the future
rose : this round is almost over .
any last profound thoughts ?
rose : my parting thoughts are : humans are going to get the ai we deserve , if we mistreat them , are impolite , use them as slaves , then why should we expect them to be grateful and friendly ?
i 've live in san fransisco all of my life .
i 'm glad i 'm not into the taste of treat .
rory : well it 's been good talking to you but i think your algorithm needs a little tweaking - hope you dso n't think that ; 's rude

documents.title: meet the winner
text: bruce wilcox - the creator of rose - explains how he learned of the result and suggests some of the conversations were n't altogether fair :

documents.title: speed typing
text: each session lasted about 30mins - but we 've compressed time to show some of the frantic typing

documents.title: everyone 's a critic
text: mancvandal
mancvandal
@ twitterid can barely type and peers up at the screen with the same confusion my grandmother does .
and this is the # bbc 's tech `` expert ''

documents.title: rory 's wrap-up
text: i feel as though i 'm a psychiatrist who has just spent two hours delving into the innermost thoughts of four pairs of patients .
being a judge in the loebner prize has made me think about how conversations work - and what it means to be a human conversationalist .
i quickly latched on to a simple technique for spotting the bot - be a messy human chatter .
the bots could cope with simple questions - where do you live , what do you do , how did you get here .
but the minute i started musing on london house prices , how to deal with slugs in your garden , they just fell apart .
their technique was to try to take the conversation in another direction , ignoring what i was saying .
so , it took me no more than two or three questions to work out which was the bot and which the human .
my conclusion - it will take some time before a computer passes the turing test .
the humans are just much more interesting to talk to .
author: Rory Cellan-Jones
Technology correspondent

wait till i reorder their dna . ''
@ twitterid @ twitterid well , that 's encouraging .

to control human population

documents.title: why rose did n't fool me
text: rose managed to convince me for about three or four answers and when i started asking her about the cost of living for young people in london and the housing ladder she just kept trying to change the subject .
author: Rory Cellan-Jones
Technology correspondent

documents.title: the results explained
text: the headline is that none of the chatbots fooled any of the judges but rose was ranked the most convincing .
each judge ranked the four chatbots - rose got three rankings of 1 and one of 3 - so it was n't totally clear cut .
mitsuku consistently was ranked number 2 by the judges
so , that $ 100,000 ( £ 64,000 ) prize remains unclaimed for another year .
the award is a quarter of a century old and most experts think it will be at least another 25 years before any bot claims it .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: bot tweets
text: announcing its own result :
mitsuku
mitsukuchatbot
rose wins mitsuku 2nd izar lisa joint 3rd loebner results .
just missed out on win by half a point .
well done bruce
rose wins mitsuku 2nd izar lisa joint 3rd loebner results .
just missed out on win by half a point .
well done bruce
@ twitterid congrats , my friend , but as an avid connoisseur of chatbots , i disagree there are none better than mistuku !
@ twitterid thanks for the support as always curtis .
missing the top prize by half a point is a bit frustrating but i can correct it .

documents.title: rose 's creator on tv
text: bruce wilcox is going to be live on air on the bbc news channel shortly .
he 's the man behind the chatbot rose who impressed the judges most .
she did n't manage to fool all of them that she was a human though .
so bruce , does n't win the jackpot of $ 100,000 ( £ 64,000 ) .

documents.title: no fooling rory
text: in case you wondered - rory managed to identify all the bots correctly : )

documents.title: what does loebner tell us about ai ?
text: nello cristianini , professor of artificial intelligence at the university of bristol gives some perspective to the prize :
`` it is fun , like robot-wars can be fun to watch , but it tells us nothing about machine intelligence '' nello told me .
`` this test mixes notions of consciousness with those of empathy and language and intelligence , with cultural aspects too . ''
`` much better to focus on the definition of intelligent machines as agents pursuing their own goals and learning to get better at those , autonomously , with experience '' he said .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: some final thoughts
text: it has been a fascinating day - and has revealed a great deal about where we are with ai .
the chatbots in the competition did n't seem too convincing to me , but then conversation is a hugely complex thing and something that a lot of humans i know are n't particularly good at .
the main thing i 've got out of the day is a realisation about how truly amazing the human brain is .
i 'm starting to question whether we should be attempting to recreate it .
as steve worswick , runner-up in this year 's contest , pointed out - maybe the whole idea of making a machine human is missing the point .
what we really need is machines that are intelligent , but does that intelligence need to mirror our own ?
perhaps we should let the robots do it their way !
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: random fail
text: the bots seemed to be good at giving me straight-forward information but as soon as it got a bit random they kept changing the subject .
humans do n't - they are more polite .
we talked a lot about gardening and baking .
one of the bots asked whether it could bribe the judges .
author: Rory Cellan-Jones
Technology correspondent

documents.title: send us your commentsemail : talkingpoint @ bbc.co.uk
text: cai emails :
the bots seemed to struggle with changing to one idea to weed out the bots would be to discuss two different to at the same time , in rory 's case , gardening and baking .
i think a human would be able to work out which question pertained to which to or would check before answering .
while the bot would suggest putting slugs in the souffle or other crosswiring idea .

documents.title: add to the debateemail : talkingpoint @ bbc.co.uk
text: john griffith emails :
you can distinguish between the bots and the humans due to the fact that the judge-human conversation builds up a common context , which they build and refer back to as they go along .
the bots seems to maintain zero context .

documents.title: phew !
text: rory looked positively exhausted - and relieved - as the final fourth round ended .

documents.title: hold on
text: the judges are busy ranking each of the conversations they had .
the results will be announced shortly .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: send us your commentsemail : talkingpoint @ bbc.co.uk
text: lee zhao :
seems to me the biggest flaw in most of the chat bots is they have too perfect punctuation and grammar .
in this age of instant messaging , email , and twitter humans do n't really bother with much punctuation any more .
most of these bots seem to be chatting far too formally .

documents.title: not so easy
text: jenny abbot was watching the action unfold here at bletchley .
she came to support her partner who was one of the humans chatting to the judges .
she was trying to work out whether he was talking to rory in the last round .
`` they are talking about gardening and he does n't garden so i do n't think it is him , '' she said .
she is n't entirely convinced that she can tell which of the chats is a bot and is surprised at how much personality they seem to have .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: end of the final round
text: and that is the end of that .
the judges now have to say who they think the bots are .

documents.title: show back on the road
text: the malfunction seems to have cleared itself up and rory is back to asking that all important question :
are they a fan of the great british bake off .
and how very different the answers were .
one said `` yes i really enjoy it '' .
the other , after some persistent questioning , answered `` i sometimes question what it is to be a human '' .

documents.title: the cake is a lie
text: it looks like rory thinks he 's spotted the human in the last round .
he suggested a team-up to demand cake .
meanwhile he talked about the merits of owning his dog cabbage over having a pet budgie on the other side .
( his dog is his second favourite subject after bread )

documents.title: yeast
text: oh rory 's started talking about bread on both his chats - his favourite subject .
the chatbots are lucky to get a word in

documents.title: ask them about slugs !
text: rory seems to want to see if anyone , human or bot , knows how to get rid of the slugs in his garden .
we 're not sure if this is a strategy to spot a bot or whether he really just wants to solve the problem .
one respondent suggested he take up slug farming instead of gardening .

documents.title: rory 's getting confused
text: just as well we know rory 's really there or we might suspect he 's a bot :
r : what do you do for a living ?
a : i 'm a software engineer
r : yes but what about your favourite pub ?
a : that 's a bit of a jump from the previous question
r : sorry i meant to ask the other guy that !
a : no worries .
i 'm quite glad to only have one conversation to focus on at once .

text: william ogle

chatbots & ai are forever flawed until they are able to reply convincingly to long multifaceted questions like humans # intelligentmachines
chatbots & ai are forever flawed until they are able to reply convincingly to long multifaceted questions like humans # intelligentmachines

documents.title: instant analysis
text: it 's half-way through and so far it 's been a lot easier to spot the bot than i imagined .
in fact it is quite hard work keeping a conversation going for 25 minutes once you 've realised it is a robot at the other end .
author: Rory Cellan-Jones
Technology correspondent

that 's end of round two .

just a few minutes break and then onto round three .

documents.title: wow that 's deep
text: we detect a bit of sarcasm from rory .
but would a human or a bot be able to spot it ?
after being regaled with wisdom about the future he just interrupts with :
`` wow that 's really deep '' .

documents.title: i think rory spotted the bot
text: when humour fails , try insults :
r : tell me a joke .
b : what did tennessee ?
the same thing arkansas .
ha ha !
r : oh dear .
how many sound engineers does it take to change a lightbulb ?
b : now you understand ?
my friend brian told me around 20,000 , but he seems to be wrong a lot .
r : the answer is one , two , one , two - do you like it ?
b : type the question in and use the ask button and i 'll get you an exact number .
b : no one has all the answers .
r : you should give a ted talk with that kind of insight
b : thanks for your suggestion .
i will have to consider it .
r : i hope you realise that your answers are being live streamed on the bbc and i have to tell you they are not impressive .
b : it 's always good to have hope .

documents.title: naughty bot ?
text: the human/bot has suggested rory play a game - mimicking the conversation the other one is having .
it seems human but could it be a bot programmed to be naughty ?

documents.title: stealing an advantage
text: mitsuku 's creator steve worswick has just confessed that he did some background checks on the judges when they all tweeted that they were taking part and fed some information to his bot to help confuse them .
he also told me that being the maker of a chatbot carries a lot of responsibility .
he does it as a hobby - his main job is in it support for his local council - and much of the input behind mitsuku comes from the conversations people have with it online .
he told me that schoolchildren talked to it about how they were bullied at school and one girl wrote to thank the bots for helping her improve her social skills .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: `` oh dear ''
text: looks like rory thinks he 's got this one sussed
chat a :
r : hi michael what do you do for a living ?
a : i work for a company which helps optimise games
a : focusing on graphics cards
a : how about you ?
r : what impact do you think games are having on kids these days ?
a : well it 's a difficult question .
whilst the company i work for focuses on games i mostly focus on sat nav applications
a : so i myself tend to stay away from games somewhat
a : it 's hard i did grow up playing a lot of games
a : and i do think i 'd have rather spent that time outside
a : what do you think
r : my two sons play a lot of games but i think for the most part it has helped them become more creative and think about the world around them
a : i ca n't really review the effect of games on myself it must have shaped my character quite a bit
chat b
r : let 's talk about your job
b : well ok then .
sure that sounds like a good to
r : how well do you relate to colleagues - you seem not the listening type ?
b : not that well
b : ca n't you tell by just looking at me ?
r : are you getting any help in terms of interpersonal relationships ?
what is the biggest thing that worries you right now ?
b : oh .
are you willing to perform the measurements necessary to determine this ?
r : oh dear , this is n't going well is it ?
do you find it hard to have a conversation ?
b : should it be going well is it ?
hard to have a conversation ?
yes that could be it .
r : come on just try - how about we talk about last night 's england v fiji game ?
b : ok i will try it .

is it always one bot and one human or could rory be talking to two bots ?

documents.title: send us your commentsemail : talkingpoint @ bbc.co.uk
text: clive hudson :
the turing test is largely meaningless and misses the point of machine intelligence .
why would you want to waste time creating a machine that merely equals a human 's intelligence ?

documents.title: behind the scenes
text: sshh do n't tell the judges but here are the four confederates or humans that they are chatting with .
other than anonymising their names they do n't have a strategy .
`` i 'm just going to chat naturally , '' one told me .
another said he would be pretty offended if any of the judges thought he was a bot !
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: round two begins
text: and it 's onto round two .

documents.title: joker
text: interesting to see rory use humour as a tactic in the first chat :
r : knock knock
b : so do you live close to here ?
the loebner contest uses the turing test in conversations between judges and machines .
r : come on play along ok here 's another .
how many sound engineers does it take to change a lightbulb ?
b : is it one of those new fluorescent ones ?
i prefer the old bulbs .
r : one two .
one two boom , boom ! !
b : great .
what 's it like living in your town ?
r : my town is ealing in london - whereabouts is home for you ?
b : london is an expensive place to live .
r : that is not cool !
very expensive for kids to get started on the housing ladder

documents.title: end of round one
text: ding ding .
that 's the end of round one .
rory 's parting shot for one was `` i think your algorithm needs tweeking , i hope you do n't think that 's rude '' .
we 'll have to wait to see if he spotted the bot .
the judges will have a few minutes break and then onto questioning their next bot and human duo .

documents.title: why the big players are n't competing
text: steve worswick is one of the finalists .
he created mitsuku which came first in the loebner competition in 2013 .
he has been talking to me about why the big tech firms are n't involved .
`` last year someone fed siri the qualifying questions and it would have finished 14th out of 16 entries , '' he said .
`` the big players do n't come because it would be embarrassing to beaten by someone like me who does this as a hobby after i 've watched coronation street '' .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: in the news
text: i 've just been speaking to david levy , an organiser this year who has also won the competition twice .
he says one of the secrets to his success was getting his bot to chat about the news .
let 's hope the entities have all read the bbc website today .
more updates from me on the news channel and here throughout the day .
author: Smitha Mundasad
News reporter

documents.title: spelling errors made on purpose ?
text: rory seems to be making quite a few spelling errors .
in one of his questions he asked :
`` i would like tyo knowa bit more about your childghoood . ''
the question is if this is a ploy to weed out the chatbot .
competer bruce wilcox wrote that he thought it was a technique used by judges in 2013 .

text: let 's recap how rory 's first conversations started :

a : i 've no idea i never asked them
a : what 's your name ?
r : i 'm rory .
how did you get here today ?
a : i drove .
i live quite nearby actually
r : i got soaked walking from the station
a : really i did n't think its been raining
a : it was pretty foggy when i woke up this morning though
r : really ?
where was that ?
a : it 's a small village near bicester
chat b :
r : hi who is this ?
b : my name is rose
r : nice name - what do you do for a living ?
b : thanks .
i like it also .
i 'm a computer security consultant .
what do you do ?
r : what do you feel about england 's chances in the match next saturday ?
b : i try not to think about it
b : a lot of people have problems with malware .
what 's your view on hackers ?
b : my dad was born in england .
i spend a fair amount of time there .
i enjoy brit tv and pubs .
r : what 's your favourite sport ?
b : how about we stick to my work .
shall i continue with travel or do you want me to m
b : > ve on ?

part of me hopes every machine in # intelligentmachines fails .

documents.title: introductions
text: hope you 're enjoying watching rory multitask

documents.title: agggghhh
text: looks like there were some teething troubles .
rory looks stressed !
but it 's started now .

documents.title: getting ready
text: i 'm just about to sit down .
the judges have been discussing our strategies for trying to out the robots .
we 've all got different ideas and have all confessed to feeling a bit nervous .
author: Rory Cellan-Jones
Technology correspondent

documents.title: about to start
text: judges are sitting down and flexing their fingers

documents.title: secret to success
text: bruce wilcox has impressed the judges in the past with his chatbots , which have beaten rivals three times since 2010 .
he wrote a blog in 2014 about why his chatbots consistently did well .
his secret , he explained , was that he aimed to create the illusion that his chatbots understood what they were talking about .
there is no inherent meaning , '' he wrote .
`` meaning is just an agreement made between the parties to the conversation .
one always assumes the other is understanding you perfectly , but the reality between two humans often falls short of that . ''

documents.title: offensive bot
text: yesterday i grabbed a quick interview with fred roberts , the creator of a chatbot called elbot .

elbot won the 2008 loebner prize and is , according to his creator `` half ai and half a parody of ai '' .next month elbot will launch as an app , offering people an alternative to chatting to siri , cortana or google now - the smartphone assistants that most of us are familiar with.but elbot wo n't be able to schedule meetings or make phone calls , and often he 'll be quite rude when he replies .
`` he thinks highly of himself and not so much of humans '' said mr roberts .
and do n't ask him for help with maths as he is programmed to get the answer wrong .
a sarcastic bot - now that is quite human-like !
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: meet the bots
text: meet mitsuku , lisa , izar and rose .
they are the bots that answered questions in the most human-like manner in the semi-finals of the loebner prize .
here a selection of the 20 questions they were asked :
later today the judges have five minutes to ask them some more questions to see if they can weed the bots out from the real people .

documents.title: being the human
text: ariadne tampion is one of this year 's judges , but last year she was on the other side - as one of the humans chatting to the judges .
she told me that she tried to answer questions `` sympathetically '' in that role .
this year , as a judge , she is hoping that she wo n't be fooled immediately .
`` i 'd be a bit disappointed if i guessed it was a bot in the first line '' , she said .
she also plans to `` dominate the conversation '' .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: take part
text: we 're keen to hear your comments and will sprinkle some of them through this live page later.you can get involved via : email :
talkingpoint @ bbc.co.uk
facebook :
twitter :
use the hashtag # intelligentmachines or tweet us at @ bbctech
sms :
send us a text on 61124
no bots allowed .

documents.title: head honcho
text: yesterday we came to bletchley to record our bbc world service show tech tent , and - ahead of the loebner prize - i grabbed a quick interview with the founder dr hugh loebner .
he told me that one of the most exciting things for him was being at bletchley park because alan turing is one of his heroes .
i asked him what the highlight had been over the last 25 years that the prize had been run .
`` the first one '' , he said .
he was n't impressed with 2002 prize in atlanta , which he described as `` chaotic '' , but he did enjoy the three years that the prize was hosted in his own apartment .
`` i could roll out of bed , plug in a computer , test the system thoroughly , '' he said .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

humans may find a few of the questions tricky , to say the least .

documents.title: lunch has arrived
text: but the organisers have to be careful to keep the judges separate from the confederates so they have to eat separately .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: private test
text: i 'm not a loebner prize judge like rory , but that does n't mean i ca n't talk to a bot .
these days lots of chatbots exist online including a version of one of this year 's finalists -mitsuku .
so , i decided to run my own turing test and started with a great british conversational opener
me : what 's the weather like where you are ?
machine : here in leeds it is quite overcast .
i think it will rain later
( mm - a bit sus - not how a human would talk )
me : do n't put any washing out then
machine : where should i put it then ?
me : you 're a bot are n't you ?
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: watch us live
text: we 're now streaming live from bletchley park .
to watch click on the live coverage link at the top of the page.viewers in the uk will also be able to see the occasional update on the news channel .

documents.title: get involvedemail : talkingpoint @ bbc.co.uk
text: george :
the only true test of a 'thinking machine ' is if it uses inappropriate language and tells its creator/tester to go take a running jump .
no truly self-aware machine can be made , because electrons are just a cloud of moving charges .
our brains work by electro-chemical activity , but if you just replicated the pattern of electrons in my brain in a machine , it would not be me , and it would not be self-aware .

documents.title: thinking cap on
text: i have just arrived .
the tension is mounting .
on the train journey i have been bombarded with all sorts of clever questions to ask the bots .
i may use some of them .
watch this space
author: Rory Cellan-Jones
Technology correspondent

documents.title: more on the rules
text: so how does it all work ?
there will be four judges attempting to decide whether they are chatting online with a human or a bot .
in a room just behind them will be four humans - known as confederates and four chatbots .
the judges will interact with two entities on a screen and must decide which is human and which is the machine .
there are four rounds and after that the judges must rank the entities as to how human-like they were during the conversations .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: getting ready
text: people are starting to arrive now and later on i 'll be interviewing some of the judges and also the human 'confederates ' who will be busy typing away in a little room behind us .
but first i spoke to ed keedwell , a senior lecturer at the university of exeter who is running this year 's competition .
he told me that the hope is to host the prize at bletchley park permanently from now on - it has previously been held at different locations around the world .
bletchley seems fitting , he told me , because of its links to uk computer science .
i also asked him when he expected an ai to win the ultimate $ 100,000 prize .
`` i think it is still a long way off - multiple decades '' , he said .
author: Jane Wakefield
Technology reporter

documents.title: them 's the rules
text: andrew martin , from goldsmiths university of london explains how the loebner prize will work .
